BALTIMORE

Nearly 400 students of the University. of Nebraska have recently
returned to their studies after
working in the mines of Nebraska
and neighboring states to help relieve tliv_ coal famine. Support
was pledged to the government at
a inass-me.oting, and resolutions
were adopted, condemning those
responsible for conditions as they
were at the time- of greatest need.
Three co-eds helped with the cooking for the men while they were at
work in the coal fields.

The IICW constitution -drawn up.
by the Athletic Board and read at
the mass-meeting of the preceding
week was unanimously passed by
the student body last Thursday.
Copies of the new constitution will
be printed and distributed among
the students.
Several proposed amendments
were discussed before the constitution was accepted, but President
Hoffman of the Athletic Board
pointed out that a constitution
could not be amended until it took
effect. General disapproval of that
section Mach gives the Athletic
Board the right to reject a captain elected by the team was expressed. It was pointed out that
the players, rather than the student body represented through the
Athletic Board, would undoubtedly be the best judges of the qualifications for athletic leaders. A
DiotiOn to annul this clause failed
to receive the necessary unanimous passage by two votes. The
snbject will be brought up again
at a future meeting.
The other section found objectionable related to the election of
managers of teams. The constitution, as written, states that men
heed not have been assistant managers to be chosen managers. At
ler some discussion, this matter
was also postponed until the next
meeting.
•Last Thursday's gathering was
distinguished from the usual massmeeting by the presence of a trio
of the Hopkins orchestra. Vanneman on the drum, Baughman on
the piano, and Rankin on the violin, performed to the great delight
of everyone present—and that future mass-meetings would be much
more satisfactory with such music
included in their programs was
the concensus of opinion.

Johns Hopkins Press

The co-eds of the University of
Cincinnati have a Man-haters'
Club. Two girls were recently requested to resign on the ground
that they had not lived up to, the
ideals of the organization. After
the business of the club had be])
transacted, an interesting paper
on "Why We Hate Men Until We
Have A Date," was read by one of
the members.

QUACKS FROM A QUACK

I

"In the spring, a young man's
fancy lightly turns to thoughts of
love." So says ye om proverb and
rightly. Spring time is upon us;
yea, even it is here, and by the
same token I have seen strange
and wonderful sights which go to
show that the young men at Hopkins are permitting themselves to
run true to form. Of course, Ferdie Meyers has set the example by
threatening marriage. That, I
think, is carrying the custom of
"obeying that impulse" a wee bit
far, I don't believe that aforesaid
old proverb intended Ferdie to do
anything quite so desperate.
But the signs of the times are
breaking out in milder forms here
and there. For instance, have you
taken careful note of that pearl
gray creation which Vertrees
Wyckoff proudly calls a hat? It
is truly a masterpiece of the art,
one in a million, but even so, no
self-respecting male being would
voluntarily of his own accord condescend to purchase such an article, much less to wear it. By
my beard, he is under the spell of
a fair maiden, as Kipling used to
say (I believe it was Kipling),
"look for the woman in the case."
But this strange and peculiar
disease affects both young and old.
It plays no favorites, none are immune. They tell me that when
"Ma" Green takes leave of a beautiful lady nowadays, it is with
words to this effect, "Good-bye,
my dear, and remember that the
present Mrs. Green is not immortal."
The taller they are the harder
they fall, and following out this
line of reasoning, let me unfold
the queer maneuvers that the
weather has caused one young gentleman to execute. Namely, Calkins, the boy the newspaper chaps
loved to dub "the blond young
giant," a regular two-fisted caveman, you know. They tell me he
has 'been seen flashing his superb
physique and wicked hair cut before the more or less admiring
brown eyes of one of the fair sex,
who condescends to grace the Civil
Engineering Building with her
charming presence. This hero of
many a bloody football battle, this
fire-eater who was afraid of nothing, tells me that this same damsel
Ii; s that strange faculty of making him shine the tip of his left
shoe against the cuff of his right
tronser, and be scared nearly to
death. Eric says that when he
goes to call in the evening he has
the same sinking nervous sensation in the immediate vicinity of
his floating ribs which was formerly aroused in him when "Doc."
Hulbert would say, "Now for the
pr-r-roblems." Another good man
gone wrong.
Still there is one consolation,
only one wild woman can get you
at once. The law firmly states
this fact, even the Bible says,"No
ma n can serve two masters."

R. O. T. C.

An inspection of the R. 0. T. C.
unit was held last Thursday with
Colonel Bull, from the headquarters of the Eastern Division as inspecting officer. After a brief inspection on the upper quadrangle,
two companies spent the rest of
the drill period in practising close
and extended order, while Company A was marched out Thirtysecond street to Lake Montebello.
Here two squads, under Corporals
"Bob" Hall and "Johnnie" Dubelle, respectively, were sent out
in the same general direction, as
reconnaissance patrols, representing hostile forces. Each was to
procure certain information; thus

the duty of each was to avoid combat at all costs. The patrols, however, came into contact and opened
fire on each other, the umpires
ruling two men in one squad
killed and two in the other captured. Colonel Bull and Captain
Ellis viewed the maneuvers
through field glasses, and when
the squads were called in, Cadet
Major Burger gave the critique.
The Lake Montebello region is
an excellent one in which to simulate actual campaign conditions,
and although time is necessarily
lost in marching there and back,
it is felt that much can be gained
by working under such excellent
conditions.

Contestants For Adams Medal

The "Foreign Student's Directory."

Upon the request of :Mr. Hammond, Dr. John C. French judged
the would-be orators in the tryouts for the Adams contest. About
12 men came out for the preliminaries. Although most of the
candidates spoke very well, Dr.
French decided that the four men
who gave evidence of being able
to make better speeches in the
final contest were Hieman, Macdonald, Marbury and Williams.
These men will show their wares
on the night of the Taqueville
Medal Contest, the date of which
will be decided upon by the Debating Council in the near future.

The "Foreign Student's Directory," is published by the committee on Friendly Relations Among
Foreign Students, 347 Madison
avenue, New York City, and contains the names of over 6,000 sturents from 80 nations; the summary indicates the number of institutions attended, classified by
states. Price 25c. For information, inquire at the Y. M. C. A.
office.
The Aero Clubs of Columbia,
Harvard and Yale are making
plans for a three-cornered airplane
race next spring.

Nearly 400 students of the University. of Nebraska have recently
returned to their studies after
working in the mines of Nebraska
and neighboring states to help relieve tliv_ coal famine. Support
was pledged to the government at
a inass-me.oting, and resolutions
were adopted, condemning those
responsible for conditions as they
were at the time- of greatest need.
Three co-eds helped with the cooking for the men while they were at
work in the coal fields.

The IICW constitution -drawn up.
by the Athletic Board and read at
the mass-meeting of the preceding
week was unanimously passed by
the student body last Thursday.
Copies of the new constitution will
be printed and distributed among
the students.
Several proposed amendments
were discussed before the constitution was accepted, but President
Hoffman of the Athletic Board
pointed out that a constitution
could not be amended until it took
effect. General disapproval of that
section Mach gives the Athletic
Board the right to reject a captain elected by the team was expressed. It was pointed out that
the players, rather than the student body represented through the
Athletic Board, would undoubtedly be the best judges of the qualifications for athletic leaders. A
DiotiOn to annul this clause failed
to receive the necessary unanimous passage by two votes. The
snbject will be brought up again
at a future meeting.
The other section found objectionable related to the election of
managers of teams. The constitution, as written, states that men
heed not have been assistant managers to be chosen managers. At
ler some discussion, this matter
was also postponed until the next
meeting.
•Last Thursday's gathering was
distinguished from the usual massmeeting by the presence of a trio
of the Hopkins orchestra. Vanneman on the drum, Baughman on
the piano, and Rankin on the violin, performed to the great delight
of everyone present—and that future mass-meetings would be much
more satisfactory with such music
included in their programs was
the concensus of opinion.

QUACKS FROM A QUACK

I

"In the spring, a young man's
fancy lightly turns to thoughts of
love." So says ye om proverb and
rightly. Spring time is upon us;
yea, even it is here, and by the
same token I have seen strange
and wonderful sights which go to
show that the young men at Hopkins are permitting themselves to
run true to form. Of course, Ferdie Meyers has set the example by
threatening marriage. That, I
think, is carrying the custom of
"obeying that impulse" a wee bit
far, I don't believe that aforesaid
old proverb intended Ferdie to do
anything quite so desperate.
But the signs of the times are
breaking out in milder forms here
and there. For instance, have you
taken careful note of that pearl
gray creation which Vertrees
Wyckoff proudly calls a hat? It
is truly a masterpiece of the art,
one in a million, but even so, no
self-respecting male being would
voluntarily of his own accord condescend to purchase such an article, much less to wear it. By
my beard, he is under the spell of
a fair maiden, as Kipling used to
say (I believe it was Kipling),
"look for the woman in the case."
But this strange and peculiar
disease affects both young and old.
It plays no favorites, none are immune. They tell me that when
"Ma" Green takes leave of a beautiful lady nowadays, it is with
words to this effect, "Good-bye,
my dear, and remember that the
present Mrs. Green is not immortal."
The taller they are the harder
they fall, and following out this
line of reasoning, let me unfold
the queer maneuvers that the
weather has caused one young gentleman to execute. Namely, Calkins, the boy the newspaper chaps
loved to dub "the blond young
giant," a regular two-fisted caveman, you know. They tell me he
has 'been seen flashing his superb
physique and wicked hair cut before the more or less admiring
brown eyes of one of the fair sex,
who condescends to grace the Civil
Engineering Building with her
charming presence. This hero of
many a bloody football battle, this
fire-eater who was afraid of nothing, tells me that this same damsel
Ii; s that strange faculty of making him shine the tip of his left
shoe against the cuff of his right
tronser, and be scared nearly to
death. Eric says that when he
goes to call in the evening he has
the same sinking nervous sensation in the immediate vicinity of
his floating ribs which was formerly aroused in him when "Doc."
Hulbert would say, "Now for the
pr-r-roblems." Another good man
gone wrong.
Still there is one consolation,
only one wild woman can get you
at once. The law firmly states
this fact, even the Bible says,"No
ma n can serve two masters."

clearly discerned and understood;

a series of strikes or threatened
strikes in many of her largest inBaltimore, Charles and Fayette "

of a nationally serious character.

controversy, and unionized labor

R. O. T. C.

An inspection of the R. 0. T. C.
unit was held last Thursday with
Colonel Bull, from the headquarters of the Eastern Division as inspecting officer. After a brief inspection on the upper quadrangle,
two companies spent the rest of
the drill period in practising close
and extended order, while Company A was marched out Thirtysecond street to Lake Montebello.
Here two squads, under Corporals
"Bob" Hall and "Johnnie" Dubelle, respectively, were sent out
in the same general direction, as
reconnaissance patrols, representing hostile forces. Each was to
procure certain information; thus

the duty of each was to avoid combat at all costs. The patrols, however, came into contact and opened
fire on each other, the umpires
ruling two men in one squad
killed and two in the other captured. Colonel Bull and Captain
Ellis viewed the maneuvers
through field glasses, and when
the squads were called in, Cadet
Major Burger gave the critique.
The Lake Montebello region is
an excellent one in which to simulate actual campaign conditions,
and although time is necessarily
lost in marching there and back,
it is felt that much can be gained
by working under such excellent
conditions.

Contestants For Adams Medal

The "Foreign Student's Directory."

Upon the request of :Mr. Hammond, Dr. John C. French judged
the would-be orators in the tryouts for the Adams contest. About
12 men came out for the preliminaries. Although most of the
candidates spoke very well, Dr.
French decided that the four men
who gave evidence of being able
to make better speeches in the
final contest were Hieman, Macdonald, Marbury and Williams.
These men will show their wares
on the night of the Taqueville
Medal Contest, the date of which
will be decided upon by the Debating Council in the near future.

The "Foreign Student's Directory," is published by the committee on Friendly Relations Among
Foreign Students, 347 Madison
avenue, New York City, and contains the names of over 6,000 sturents from 80 nations; the summary indicates the number of institutions attended, classified by
states. Price 25c. For information, inquire at the Y. M. C. A.
office.
The Aero Clubs of Columbia,
Harvard and Yale are making
plans for a three-cornered airplane
race next spring.

LOSES BOUT BY DECISION
Ted Dorsey Loses by Referee's Decision
to Kid Geary, of Fort McHenry, in
Fast Four-Round Bout at the
American Legion Circus.

In the fastest bout of the evening at the American Legion Circus last Saturday night, "Ted"
Dorsey, a member of the Hopkins
Boxing Team, and representing
the Central Young Men's Christian Association, lost the referee's
decision to "Kid" Geary, of Fort
McHenry. The match was for only four rounds, and Dorsey seemed
to be improving all the time, although he had taken quite a bit
of punishment and had had one
eye closed by his opponent.

received a great deal of criticism
